_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EPA RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN	

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

TRIDENT SEAFOODS CORP, KODIAK, AK.

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES.
 
Using the guidelines and directives spelled out by OSHA in the Process Safety Management standard to protect workers and contractors in our facility, and EPAA¿s Risk Management Program which focuses on the protection of the public and the environment, Trident Seafoods Corporation has developed a management system with a plan responsible for the following: 
	.  An assessment of the hazards of a chemical release.  
	.  The development of a prevention program.  
	.  The development of an emergency action program. 
  
2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

Regulated substances: Ammonia (anhydrous)
Amount of regulated substance:  34,300 lbs.
Trident Seafoods Corporation, Kodiak, Alaska, facility is a fresh frozen seafood processing plant.  Cod, pollock, halibut, sole, rockfish, salmon, crab, and other species are processed into fillets, blocks, or whole products and surimi.  These are then frozen in spiral freezers, plate or blast freezers and shipped to buyers and processors in the United States and around the world.  Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the refrigeration process.

3. THE GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM.

This facility complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations Chemical Process Safety Management 29 CFR 1910.119 and the Environmental Protection Agencies Risk Management Program 40 CFR Part 68.
Trident Seafoods Corporation follows state, local,and industry guidelines, as well as recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices for system operation and maintenance.  Fundamental for the success of our program is employee participation.  Employee participation is needed to develop other parts of the program including training, standard operating procedures, process hazard analysis, management of change, pre-startup safety review, mecha

nical integrity, process safety information, incident investigation, hot work permits, contractor qualifications, compliance audits and emergency response.   

4. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.

There have been no recordable accidents in the last 5 years. 


5. THE EMERGENCY ACTION PROGRAM.

In the event of a catastrophic release (more than 100 pounds of ammonia), the plant will  evacuate.  Emergency Response Team members under supervision from the Emergency Response Coordinator using the proper personal protective equipment may use fans or other defensive devices to protect employees while they evacuate.  
Trained Kodiak Hazmat Responders arriving onscene along with trained Trident Hazmat technicians will initiate offensive tactics and manage emergency situations.  

A written Emergency Action Plan has been developed and is on record at the facility.  This plan includes Pre-Emergency Planning with Outside Agencies, Personnel Roles and Lines of Incident Command Authority, Facility Hazard Analysis and Emergency Prevention, Safe Distances, and Places of Refuge, Site Security and Control, Evacuation Routes and Procedures, Decontamination Procedures, provisions for Emergency Medical Treatment, Emergency Notification Procedure, Chemical Response Procedures, Post Incident Critique, and Personal Protective Clothing and Emergency Equipment.

All Hazmat courses at Trident Seafoods Corp are designed to meet training requirements of the OSHA 29 CFR1910.120 (q) (7) and (8).

All Kodiak, AK Hazmat Team Members are trained 24 hours initially to the Technician level followed by 8-24 hours of refresher training per year under the direction of the on-site Hazmat Instructor at the facility.  Each instructor receives an initial 40 hours of training and 8-16 hours per year re-certification training that goes to I.C. level.

The training is designed to teach both theory and hands-on training giving the person an overall understanding of the nature of the hazardous materia

ls and the ability to assess and safely respond to the incidents in the incident Command structure.  Technician level training includes but is not limited to the following:

- Knowledge of basic hazards and risk assessment techniques
- Proper selection and use of appropriate and required PPE for the chemical hazard
- Terminology associated with Hazmat
- Advanced control/security procedures
- Advanced Containment/Control /Deon procedures
- Use of Atmospheric Monitoring Equipment and Containment Test Procedures
- Incident Command Structure Roles and Line of Authority 
- Interaction with Local and State officials
- Standard Operation Procedures of Clean-up and termination
- Critique

All training material hands on drills and response procures have been developed under the direction of the Corporate Regulatory Affairs Department.  There is a yearly Hazmat ammonia response drill conducted where the combined skills of the Trident Kodiak Plant emergency responders and the community Hazmat Team are practiced.


6. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.

Any changes other than like in kind are documented in the Management of Change section of the Process Safety Management/Risk Management plan.  Safety is the cornerstone of any change in the plant.
